intro: Phyllodoce × intermedia, commonly known as the intermediate mountain-mahogany, is a shrub native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils in alpine and subalpine regions. It has a low, spreading growth habit with dark green leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white wax. Phyllodoce × intermedia is an important component of high-elevation ecosystems, providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
